Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Subspace Matching and Approximation on the Continuum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
In a diverse range of application areas--including astronomical
imaging, microscopy, wireless communications, radar, sonar, and
many others--one must confront the problem of estimating or
extracting information from a signal that is governed by a small
number of unknown (continuous-valued) parameters. Customized to
each of these applications, unique methods for handling these
unknown parameters have been proposed in the past. This research
involves the development of a unified framework for addressing
problems in all of these areas systematically, efficiently, with
awareness of the fundamental limits, and with provable accuracy.

There are two main components of this framework. The first
component involves the development of models where the signals of
interest lie within or close to a subspace or a union of subspaces.
In the case where the underlying parameters for the signal are
continuous-valued, this is a challenging task. Rather than attempt
to simply discredit these problems (a program potentially fraught
with difficulty), this research involves the development of finite
approximations for a locally infinite range of subspaces using
efficient local subspace fits whose dimensions match the effective
number of local degrees of freedom. The second component of this
framework consists of techniques for identifying the range of
subspaces responsible for generating a signal from a set of
discrete observations, confronting difficulties posed by the
coherence, by the continuous nature of the parameter space, and by
the fact that some signals may be synthesized from a narrow (but
continuously-indexed and therefore infinite) range of subspaces.
These components combine to enable the efficient acquisition,
processing, and estimation of signals arising from the
parameterized subspaces model.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There were two central themes for the major outcomes for this project.  The first was the development of the Fast Slepian Transform.  The second was an understanding of how a priori information about range constraints in a scene can be exploited in computational imaging.  We describe these below.

The Slepian transform is a way to represent signals that are bandlimited (i.e. have frequency content limited in a certain range) and observed over a finite interval of time.  While this type of representation has been used in signal processing since the 1970s (especially in the subfield of spectral estimation), its use had never become widespread, mostly because there was no known algorithm for computing it efficiently.  One of the key findings of this research was a suite of algorithms for signal processing with the Slepian transform that had the same efficiency as the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT), the workhorse of frequency-domain techniques.  This work was published as a series of mathematical papers, but the broader impacts include more accurate algorithms for source localization and tracking in radar and sonar applications, and new techniques for time-frequency analysis.

It is a classical result that the spatial resolution of an active imaging device is directly tied to its aperture and the bandwidth of the signal used to excite the scene --- the scene can be effectively sampled by exciting it with different frequencies and then measuring the return at different locations within the aperture.  Another major finding in this research program was that when the scene is structured, in that the range of the reflectors is very narrow at every angle, then the number of spatial samples we need to measure can be reduced as the bandwidth of the excitation grows.  This was established by posing the problem as a matrix compression ("sketching") problem, and developing new mathematics for the type of structures induced by the active imaging scenario. 

The PIs on this project also developed an open set of lecture notes and exercise problems for an undergraduate probability course.  These materials are freely available, and have been widely adopted both by the PI's institutions and elsewhere.
